journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Effect of hygrothermal conditioning on the fracture toughness of carbon/epoxy composites cured in autoclave/Quickstep

article-meta.aff: 1Centre for Emerging Sciences, Engineering and Technology (CESET), Islamabad, Pakistan
2Department of Textile Engineering, NED University of Engineering & Technology, Karachi, Pakistan
3School of Chemicals and Materials Engineering, National University of Sciences and Technology, H-12, Islamabad, Pakistan
4Professor of Composites Engineering, Glyndŵr University, Wales, UK

author-notes.corresp: Ali Hasan Mahmood, Department of Textile Engineering, NED University of Engineering & Technology, Karachi 75270, Pakistan. Email: alinedian@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The hygrothermal effect on the flexural, interfacial and glass transition behaviors of 977-2A carbon/epoxy composites cured in an autoclave and by using Quickstep were evaluated in the previous paper. This article concerns with the hygrothermal effect on the mode I and mode II delamination resistance of the samples cured in an autoclave and by Quickstep. It was observed that the mean initiation and propagation GC values (i.e. GIC and GIIC) of both autoclave and Quickstep 60 cured specimens were apparently reduced after hygrothermal conditioning; however, the data obtained from both autoclave and Quickstep 60 cured specimens in dry and wet states were not statistically significant. The scanning electron micrograph confirmed the enhancement of matrix ductility; however, no effect of this matrix ductility was observed in the GIC and GIIC data.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymer matrix composites used in aerospace and other applications may be exposed to environments usually involving temperature and humidity. It is evident from the literature that both physical and mechanical properties of composites are strongly affected during hygrothermal conditioning, which eventually reduces the overall performance of composites.1,2 The way in which composite materials absorb moisture depends upon certain factors such as temperature, fiber orientation, density and polarity of fiber, fiber volume fraction, diffusivity, etc.2 The most common moisture transport mechanism in polymeric composites is through diffusion which is explained by Adamson.3 Transport of moisture in epoxy composites below Tg, occurs in three stages. In the first stage, absorbed moisture occupies the free volume present in the form of ‘holes’ or voids. In the second stage, the absorbed moisture attacks the polymeric network sites resulted in the form of swelling and in the third stage, water finally enters the densely cross-linked region. The other common mechanisms are capillarity and transport through micro-cracks and voids. The last mechanism can be activated after material damage produced by water.

Effects of moisture can be observed in the fiber, resin and fiber–matrix interface. Most of the glass and carbon reinforcements are not susceptible to moisture absorption because of good hydrolytic stability. Aramid fibers are reported to be more vulnerable to moisture absorption and may absorb more moisture than the resin.4

In polymeric composites, the most exposed constituent to moisture is resin. Physical changes like plasticization and swelling and chemical changes like hydrolysis and chemical scission are usually severe and these can lead to significant reductions in strength and toughness properties. Plasticization is a well-documented phenomenon for thermosets and thermoplastic polymers and is found to be deleterious to a number of materials properties especially at elevated temperatures.5

The structural integrity and lifetime performance of polymeric composites are strongly dependent on the stability of fiber–matrix interfacial region.2 The fiber–matrix interface can be affected by moisture absorption, destroying the fiber bonding and providing space for the water to reside. Composite processing techniques can affect the hygrothermal behavior of composites because it is mainly a function of the resulting quality of the cured composites.

Delamination is a common damage mode of high performance composites, which can be particularly detrimental for structural behavior. This mode of failure depends not only upon the external loading conditions but also on the intrinsic properties of fiber and resin. It may also be introduced during processing or subsequent service conditions. In addition to these factors, the moisture and temperature may also induce the interlaminar stresses in the laminate. The environmental conditions considerably affect the mode I and mode II interlaminar fracture toughness (critical strain energy release rate GIC (for mode I) and GIIC (for mode II)) of polymeric composites but, no general trend can be observed from the literature for carbon/epoxy composites.

No significant change on GIC was observed when graphite/epoxy specimens were subjected to hygrothermal conditioning of 70℃ and 50% RH for 98 days and a slight reduction in transverse fracture toughness was observed when the specimens were subjected to same condition for 62 days; however, a significant reduction in mode II delamination resistance of the specimens was observed.6,7 Fischer and Arendts8 reported the effect of temperature on mode I delamination resistance of carbon/epoxy composites and no significant change was observed until 80℃; however, a significant improvement in GIC was observed when the specimens were tested between 80℃ and 120℃. Zhao and Michael9 investigated the moisture effect on the mode II fracture toughness of two types of carbon/epoxy composites and observed different rate of reductions in GIIC for both types of specimens. Russell and Street10 found a reduction in GIC with the increase in temperature but the propagation values increased with increasing temperature. An opposite trend was observed by Davidson et al.11 where GIC increased with temperature and humidity. It is important to note that the increase in the strain energy release rate was especially strong for moisturized specimens at relatively high temperatures.12

Currently, high performance composites parts are predominantly manufactured by the use of prepreg materials and autoclave cure. This requires high manufacturing temperature, pressure and a cycle time of several hours. As the aerospace timescale requirements are shortening, an increase in production rates is required and this is difficult to achieve with traditional autoclave manufacturing. Also, high capital expenditure, infrastructure requirements and time to commission has made autoclave processing, increasingly undesirable. Thus, the area of need arises in terms of speedy manufacturing and low production cost without sacrificing part quality.

Quickstep (QS) is a novel polymer composite processing technique designed and developed in Australia for out-of-autoclave processing of high quality, low cost components in comparatively short cure cycle times.13–15 The technique is based on a unique fluid filled, balanced pressure, floating mould technology for the curing, partial curing and joining of prepregs and dry fiber/wet resin based composites.

The cure schedule provided by a prepreg manufacturer is usually designed for autoclave or other traditional processing techniques and the thermosetting resin systems are usually formulated for low ramp rate curing (typically 2–3 K/min). While in case of Quickstep, ramp rates of up to 15 K/min can be achieved, thus changing the chemorheology of the resin system.16 This also affects the overall quality of the product.

The 977-2A carbon/epoxy prepreg is used in aircraft primary and secondary structure, ballistics, cryogenic tanks, space structure or any application where there is a requirement of impact resistance and light weight.17 The impact of hygrothermal conditioning on composite material behavior is of significant importance since it can result in the deterioration of structural components with the change in storage and operating conditions.2 The investigation of the long-term durability of the composites panels fabricated from novel Quickstep and traditional autoclave is, hence, of paramount importance.

The effect of the environmental conditioning on the flexural, interfacial and glass transition behavior of the composites panels manufactured from autoclave and Quickstep was presented in the previous paper.18 This article deals with the effect of hygrothermal conditioning on the mode I and mode II delamination resistance of the samples cured in an autoclave and by using Quickstep.

sec.title: Material system
sec.p: Cytec Cycom977-2A-based prepreg containing epoxy resin was used in this study which is made up of woven 6 K HTA carbon fiber having volume fraction of 63%. The cured ply thickness was measured as 0.362 mm.

sec.title: Processing of the laminates
sec.p: In this study, 5 harness satin weave is used and since it is asymmetric about its mid plane, in order to avoid any fiber deformation in the part after cure, the plies are laid up in such a way that the laminate has balanced fiber direction through its thickness.

For this purpose, it is assumed that warp dominated side is on the top and that if it is on the bottom, it would be considered as flipped. In this work, the plies were stacked in the warp direction back-to-back like flipped pairs so that the whole stacking sequence was semi-symmetric about the mid plane [0/0f].19 The dimensions of the prepared laminates are width = 200 mm, length = 200 mm and nominal thickness = 3.2 mm. All the laminates composed of six plies [0/0f]3 were with their fibers aligned in the warp direction. The laminates were vacuum bagged and cured. The cure cycles employed for autoclave processing and for Quickstep processing (based on chemo-rheology information of the neat resin) were similar as stated in the previous publication.18 Three cured panels made-up from each cure cycle were subjected to conditioning (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Processing of laminates: (a) Quickstep and (b) autoclave.

sec.title: Environmental conditioning
sec.p: The cured composite panels were subjected to hygrothermal conditioning in a Binder climatic chamber, model KBF 115. Before the conditioning process, the composites specimens were dried at 105℃ for at least 3 h. Procedure B of ASTM standard D5229 M-92 was used for selecting the conditions for equilibrium conditioning of the specimen before they were further characterized.20

The climatic chamber was set to 70℃ and 85% RH during conditioning and the weight of panels was monitored continuously as a function of time until the limit of saturation (constant weight) was achieved. It is important to maintain the temperature of the composites well below the glass transition temperature so that any irreversible damage can be avoided which permanently changes the absorption behavior of the material.21

sec.title: Characterization equipment and procedures
sec.p: Mode I and mode II interlaminar fracture toughness was determined using double cantilever beam (DCB) apparatus) according to ASTM D 5528-0122 whereas, mode II interlaminar fracture toughness testing was carried out through mixed mode bending (MMB) according to ASTM D 6671-01.23 The testing was performed on an Instron 5564 test machine.

Hinges were bonded to both the DCB and MMB test specimen for load introduction. A 15 µm thick PTFE film was inserted between the central layers of the laminate prior to processing to produce an initial delamination crack. The dimensions of specimens were 160 × 20 × 3 mm3. Four specimens were tested from each panel. A crosshead speed of 1 mm/min was selected for all the specimens.

The strain energy release rate (GIC and GIIC) the correction factors and other necessary calculation for mode I and mode II interlaminar fracture toughness were performed according to the above stated ASTM standards.22,23

sec.title: Scanning electron microscope
sec.p: The scanning electron microscope (SEM) is a type of electron microscope which is capable of producing high-resolution images of sample surfaces. For the fiber-reinforced composites, it is a very important tool for post-fracture analysis of composites surfaces. In this study, SEM was used to investigate the fracture surfaces of composite samples after they were subjected to mode I and mode II interlaminar fracture toughness testing. The composite samples were examined using a Philips model XL30 field emission gun (FEG) SEM microscope. Small sections of mode I and mode II fractured surfaces were cut from test samples and were placed on metal stubs using double-sided carbon tabs. The stubs with the fracture surfaces were then coated with a very thin layer of carbon using Edwards S150B sputter coater in order to enhance the conductivity of the surface.

sec.title: Moisture absorption
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows plots of percent moisture absorption versus square root of time in days for panels cured in an autoclave and using Quickstep for mode I and mode II testing. Two panels cured using each manufacturing technique were conditioned at 70℃ and 85% RH. The nature of the two curves in Figure 2 indicates a Fickian diffusion pattern and remains concave to the time axis until maximum moisture content (Mm) is reached. Generally, Fickian diffusion takes place at low temperatures and materials exposed to humid air and deviation from Fickian nature usually occurs when the material exposed to elevated temperature or immersed in water.24 Figure 2.
Moisture gain (%) as a function of square root of time in days for autoclave and Quickstep cured panels.

The average panel thicknesses, the equilibrium moisture content and diffusivity co-efficient for autoclave and QS-cured panels are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Average panel thicknesses, the equilibrium moisture content and diffusivity co-efficient for autoclave and Quickstep 60 cured panels.
Panels Average panel thickness (mm) Equilibrium moisture content Mm (%) Diffusivity co-efficient Dz (mm2/s)
Autoclave 3.30 0.735 ± 0.007 1.00 × 10−6
Quickstep 3.42 0.741 ± 0.005 1.51 × 10−6

Figure 2 and Table 1 illustrate that the equilibrium moisture content obtained from the autoclave and QS-60 cured panels were same. It seems contradictory to the results of previous published work18 that QS-cured panels have slightly higher moisture absorption because of the high resin content and high cross-link density of the polymer network. This is thought to be due to moisture residing in the delaminated surfaces which were induced in both autoclave and QS-60 cured panels to initiate cracks for mode I and mode II fracture toughness testing.

It is evident from Table 1, however, that the value of diffusivity co-efficient (Dz) for the QS-cured panel was about 33% greater than Dz measured for the autoclave cured panel. This is very close to the result presented in the previous work18 where the value of Dz for QS-60 cured panel was about 39% greater than the autoclave cured panel. These data are in agreement with the observation that that water diffused into the QS-cured panel at a faster rate than into the autoclave cured panel.

sec.title: Mode I fracture toughness testing
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows typical load versus crosshead displacement curves for DCB tests performed on specimens fabricated using the autoclave and QS-60 cure cycles respectively and hygrothermally conditioned at 70℃ and 85% RH. Initially, the applied load was found to increase linearly due to the implanted delamination for both autoclave and QS-cured specimens until the initiation of the crack propagation. With the growth of the crack, the load experienced several load drops until the desired delamination of the DCB specimen reached. The critical load and the crack length were recorded at the onset of the crack propagation and on desired points during crack propagation. Figure 3.
Load–displacement curves for hygrothermal conditioned mode I specimens manufactured using: (a) autoclave and (b) Quickstep cure cycle.

The mode I crack initiation and propagation energy of the dry and wet specimens manufactured using an autoclave and Quickstep are shown in Figure 4(a) and (b) respectively. Error bars have been omitted for clarity; however, the mean values along with error bars of the initiation and propagation data are provided in Figure 5. It can be seen that both autoclave and QS-cured wet samples demonstrated reduction in the average values of GIC as compared to the values in the dry state (Figure 5). Due to a large spread in the data, statistical analysis was performed in order to investigate hygrothermal effect on the fracture toughness properties. Two samples ‘t-test’ was performed on the fracture toughness data obtained from both autoclave and QS-cured specimens in dry and wet states and it was found that by conventional criteria, the difference was considered to be statistically not significant. Figure 4.
Initiation and propagation values for mode I testing of dry (un-aged) and wet (conditioned) cured specimens: (a) autoclave and (b) Quickstep.
Figure 5.
Comparison of the mean initiation (visual, 5% offset) and propagation GIC values for mode I DCB testing of dry and wet autoclave and Quickstep 60 cured specimens.

Chou25 investigated the moisture absorption effects on the interlaminar fracture toughness of carbon fiber/epoxy composites and observed a slight reduction in GIC initiation values and very high reduction in propagation values of wet samples as compared to dry state. However, other cases were also reported where no effect of moisture was observed on initiation GIC values10,26 and an increase in GIC values with increasing moisture content.12,27

The increase in GIC values with increasing temperature and/or moisture is reported as a result of matrix ductility due to matrix plasticization or due to the extent of fiber bridging.12,27 As statistically no significant effect of hygrothermal conditioning was observed on mode I delamination resistance of both autoclave and QS-cured specimens, fractographic investigations were performed using a SEM in order to identify any change in the fracture morphology due to moisture absorption.

Figure 6 presents a typical example of the mode I fracture morphology of the wet autoclave and QS-60 cured specimens. The SEM images are presented at a magnification of 500×. It can be observed that wet samples exhibited both matrix and interfacial failure. This can be attributed to the matrix ductility due to matrix plasticization; however, from Figure 5, it is evident that the extent of matrix ductility was not sufficient to introduce any effect on the delamination resistance values. Figure 6.
Scanning electron micrographs of mode I fracture surfaces of hygrothermal conditioned: (a) autoclaveb and (b) Quickstep-cured sample.

sec.title: Mode II fracture toughness testing
sec.p:
Figure 7 shows typical load versus crosshead displacement curves for the mixed mode bending tests to determine GIIC, performed on specimens fabricated using the autoclave and QS-60 cure cycles and hygrothermal conditioned at 70℃ and 85% RH. Initially, the load increases linearly with the deflection at the mid-span to the initiation point and then the load–deflection curve becomes non-linear. With the growth of the crack, the load experienced several load drops until the desired delamination of the MMB specimens was reached. The critical load and the crack length were recorded at the onset of the crack propagation and on desired points during crack propagation. Figure 7.
Load–displacement curves for wet mode II specimens of: (a) autoclave and (b) Quickstep-cured samples.

The mode II crack initiation and propagation energy of autoclave and QS-cured specimens in dry and wet states are shown in Figure 8(a) and (b), respectively. Error bars have been omitted for clarity; however, the mean values along with error bars of the initiation and propagation data are provided in Figure 9. Figure 8.
Initiation and propagation values for mode II testing of dry (un-aged) and wet (conditioned) cured specimens: (a) autoclave and (b) Quickstep.
Figure 9.
Comparison of the mean values of GIIC (visual, 5% offset and propagation) for mode II testing of dry and wet autoclave and Quickstep 60 cured specimens.

It can be seen that both autoclave and QS-cured wet samples demonstrated a reduction in the average GIIC values as compared to the values in the dry state (Figure 9). Due to large spread in the data, however, statistical analysis was performed in order to investigate hygrothermal effect on the fracture toughness properties.

The two samples t-test was performed on the fracture toughness data obtained from both autoclave and QS-cured specimens in dry and wet states. Unlike data obtained from mode I testing, it was found that by the conventional criteria, the differences were not the statistically same for all cases, as depicted from Table 2. Table 2.
Statistical significance of the GIIC data.
GIIC values comparison – dry and wet Statistical significance
Autoclave initiation – Visual (dry–wet) Not significant
Quickstep initiation – Visual (dry–wet) Significant
Autoclave initiation – 5% offset (dry–wet) Not significant
Quickstep initiation – 5% offset (dry–wet) Significant
Autoclave propagation (dry–wet) Not significant
Quickstep propagation (dry–wet) Not significant

It is evident from Table 2 that the data obtained for GIIC is statistically inconclusive. Studies on the effect of temperature and moisture on the mode II delamination toughness have been fairly uniform unlike mode I delamination toughness. GIIC has most commonly observed to decrease with increasing moisture content7,12,27–29 while in some studies, no effect of moisture absorption was reported for ASI/3501-6 and T800/924 carbon/epoxy composites, respectively.10,26 The most common degradation mechanism for GIIC due to moisture absorption was cited as fiber/matrix bond strength reduction due to matrix plasticization; however in one case, changes in the matrix properties have also been cited as a potential contributory factor.30

Figure 10 presents typical example of the mode II fracture morphology of the wet autoclave and QS-60 cured specimens. It can be observed that (similar to mode I fractured surfaces in Figure 6) in contrast to the dry state, wet samples exhibited both matrix and interfacial failure. This can again be attributed to the matrix ductility due to matrix plasticization; however, from Figure 9, it is evident that the extent of matrix ductility was not sufficient to introduce any effect on the delamination resistance values. Figure 10.
Scanning electron micrographs of mode II fractured surfaces of hygrothermal conditioned: (a) autoclave and (b) Quickstep-cured samples.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The effect of hygrothermal conditioning on the mode I fracture toughness was investigated on autoclave and QS-cured specimens and apparently, the reduction in the mean values of visual, 5% offset and propagation values of GIC for both autoclave and QS-60 cured specimens were observed. However, due to high spread in the data, the two-sample ‘t-test’ were performed and the data obtained from both autoclave and QS-60 cured specimens in dry and wet states were not statistically significant. The SEM micrograph confirmed the enhancement of matrix ductility; however, no effect of this matrix ductility was observed in the GIC data.

The effect of hygrothermal conditioning on the mode II fracture toughness was investigated on autoclave and QS-60 cured specimens and again apparently, the reduction in the mean values of visual, 5% offset and propagation values of GIIC for both autoclave and QS-60 cured specimens were observed. However, the data obtained from both autoclave and QS-60 cured specimens were statistically inconclusive. The SEM micrograph confirmed the enhancement of matrix ductility again; however, no effect of this matrix ductility was observed in the GIIC data.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge Higher Education Commission (HEC) of Pakistan for providing funds and support to pursue this research work.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
